Award.AwardTitle: Young Children's Causal Learning from Probabilistic Social and Physical Displays

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
DRL: 1251702

Abstract

This purpose of this project is to explore the origins of scientific reasoning in early childhood through innovative experiments investigating young children?s learning about probabilistic cause-effect relationships in informal settings. Children?s ability to learn from observing probabilistic causal outcomes is an ecologically valid, but understudied issue with implications for STEM educational theory and practice. Much of the causal learning that takes place in infancy and early childhood is by the observation of other people?s actions. Crucially, learning about causes in informal, non-laboratory settings means that an observer often needs to learn cause-effect relationships from probabilistic evidence?observing relations or patterns that do not occur with 100% certainty. This proposal has three objectives: To establish whether young children learn about physical causal relationships from the observation of probabilistic evidence; To investigate whether young children learn about social causal relationships from the observation of probabilistic causal evidence; To investigate whether young children observing a confounded causal system preferentially attribute probabilistic outcomes to variability in social causes or to variability in physical causes.

This project proposes a series of five converging experiments using a newly established methodology to examine the developmental roots of probabilistic causal reasoning in children as young as 24 months of age. In Experiments 1 and 2 young children will observe probabilistic causal displays involving physical objects. In Experiments 3 and 4 children will observe a pattern of probabilistic causal evidence between social agents?people interacting with one another?instead of physical objects. In Experiment 5 children will observe a confounded probabilistic causal display in which the probabilistic nature of the causal relationship could either be attributed to the person performing the intervention or to the physical object being acted upon. In each experiment, the dependent measure is what goal-directed action children take on their own to achieve the outcome based on what they observed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Learning about causality is fundamental to child development and human cognition. This project focused on a new form of causal learning in infancy, termed “observational causal learning.” What makes this learning mechanism distinctive is that infants can learn about causal relations from observing the outcomes of other’s actions, prior to and without taking their own actions. We used a new observational causal learning paradigm to investigate young children’s understanding of both deterministic and probabilistic causality.

In everyday life, many causal events occur deterministically (100% certainty). For example, in a billiard ball collision, the second ball will be launched by the first based on the laws of physics. However, there are other significant events that only occur more probabilistically (i.e., some but not all the time, <100% certainty). Both are important sources of causal learning for young children. There have been many developmental studies of physical causal learning with deterministic displays. However, neither social causal learning, nor learning from probabilistic causal chains have been systematically investigated. Social relations are deeply probabilistic given people’s penchants, idiosyncrasies, and moods. The ability to learn from the imperfect causal evidence of the everyday world, and to learn from the interactions of both people and things, would be a useful learning mechanism for young children prior to language. 

In this project, we explored infants’ probabilistic causal learning from both social and physical displays. There were two chief journal papers, each with multiple converging experiments. In one paper, we presented 24-month-old participants with probabilistic causal displays involving physical objects. The participants were not allowed to touch or handle the objects before the test. They were then given a chance to intervene to achieve the outcome based on what they had observed. This assessed the infants’ ability to learn from probabilistic physical causality. In a second paper, 24-month-olds observed a pattern of probabilistic causal evidence between social agents (people interacting with one another). This assessed infants’ ability to learn about probabilistic causal relationships involving people.

The results from the first paper showed that infants can learn cause-and-effect from observing physical probabilistic displays, and moreover that they use this information to plan their own causal actions. They successfully execute their own interventions to bring about the same effect. The findings support the inference that infants use their sensitivity to “statistical patterns” of evidence to learn the causal structure of the physical world, despite the uncertain/probabilistic evidence they receive.

The second paper advances what we know about observational causal learning in three ways. First, it showed that infants learned both in the case of physical causality and social causality – when the acts made another person do something. Second, it demonstrated that infants can learn causal relations via third-party observation—by “eavesdropping” on social interactions between other people, in the absence of specific dyadic teaching directed towards the infants themselves. Third, the findings showed that infants achieve observational causal learning under both deterministic and probabilistic conditions for both social and physical causality.

Taken together, the results from this project suggest that observational causal learning is a fundamental learning mechanism in infancy. It contributes to the rapid cultural learning that takes place prior to linguistic and didactic instruction, based simply on infants’ analysis of the statistical patterns in the physical and social world. The publications arising from this project contribute to theories of social cognition and cognitive development, with implications for neural learning mechanisms and early education. Moreover, the University of Washington’s I-LABS, disseminated the scientific discoveries to an array of audiences through multiple outlets including: (a) interactive science exhibits, (b) teacher training modules, (c) webinars delivered to nationwide child welfare groups, (d) academic presentations to developmental and cognitive scientists, and (e) state, national and international policymaking groups.
